item.title: training monitoring with Visdom and Hyperdash
item.description:
For the past few months, I have enjoyed using Visdom and Hyperdash to monitor training processes.

Visdom

Visom is a Python library developed by Facebook Research. Similar to Tensorboard, it provides a UI server (using React) through which user can create scatter plots, histograms, visualize images and text.

I have written a small snippet for creating and updating a scatter plot, which can be used for visualizing training and validation loss and accuracy.

# pip install visdom numpy
# visualize.py
import numpy
from visdom import Visdom

class Plot(object):
    def __init__(self, title, port=8080):
        self.viz = Visdom(port=port)
        self.windows = {}
        self.title = title

    def register_scatterplot(self, name, xlabel, ylabel):
        win = self.viz.scatter(
            X=numpy.zeros((1, 2)),
            opts=dict(title=self.title, markersize=5, xlabel=xlabel, ylabel=ylabel)
        )
        self.windows[name] = win

    def update_scatterplot(self, name, x, y):
        self.viz.updateTrace(
            X=numpy.array([x]),
            Y=numpy.array([y]),
            win=self.windows[name]
        )

In my training script, I can initialize and update the plots.

# train.py
import visualize

plot = visualize.Plot("Model A")
plot.register_scatterplot("Loss", "Epoch", "Loss")
for n in range(epoch):
    # ... compute average loss over training data
    plot.update_scatterplot("Loss", n + 1, loss)

Before running the training script, we need to start the web server, so that after training starts, we can go to localhost:8080 in the browser to see the plots.

python -m visdom.server -p 8080

The above snippets can also be found here. PyTorchNet library provides more loggers for plots, images, and text, it can be very handy if you’re a PyTorch user.

Hyperdash

Visdom is great for visualizing plots and images, however connection to a remote server isn’t always available. Hyperdash can stream training logs from a process on a remote server directly to my phone. I can simply open the mobile app to know if the training process died, or loss is no longer decreasing. The set up is quite simple, all necessary steps are documented in the homepage. One caveat is that it does not work well with tqdm (see issue 63), simply disable tqdm in the training script.

item.title: a minimal training plot server
item.description:
Training a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) can be a lengthy process. We usually want to monitor training loss and accuracy and validation loss and accuracy by plotting how these metrics change as the number of minibatches grows on a graph. Tensorflow provides Tensorboard for visualizing training progress. Recently I have been playing with PyTorch, I really like its expresiveness and flexibility. Here’s a strategy for visualizing training progress with any learning framework that doesn’t provide Tensorboard-equivalent feature out of the box using Python 3.

First of all as a good practice we output relevant metrics into a log file, the log file should be structured in a way that is easy to parse and extract metrics. We will need to write a parser method, and a plot method to generate desired graph(s). matplotlib, seaborn, ggplot or bokeh are useful python libraries for graphing.

Then we can use asyncio to create a background job to plot the metrics we want to visualize and use aiohttp to create a web server that displays and refreshes the graph(s) at a certain interval.

# Using python 3.4
import asyncio
import argparse
from aiohttp import web


GRAPH_LOCATION = "static/train_plot.png"


def parser(log_file):
    # read log_file and extract metrics such as
    # minibatch number, training loss, training accuracy,
    # validation loss, validation accuracy
    return metrics


def plot(metrics, output=GRAPH_LOCATION):
    # save output image to GRAPH_LOCATION


def plot_loop(args, loop):
    print("Updating plot")
    metrics = parser(args.log_file)
    plot(metrics)
    loop.call_later(args.interval, plot_loop, args, loop)


@asyncio.coroutine
def handler(request):
    interval = int(request.GET.get('interval', 30))
    resp = web.StreamResponse(status=200,
                              reason='OK',
                              headers={'Content-Type': 'text/html'})

    yield from resp.prepare(request)

    html_str = """
        <html>
            <head>
                <meta http-equiv='refresh' content='{}'>
            </head>
            <body>
                <img src='{}' width='100%'/>
            </body>
        </html>
    """.format(interval, GRAPH_LOCATION)
    resp.write(str.encode(html_str))

    yield from resp.drain()
    return resp


@asyncio.coroutine
def build_server(loop, address, port):
    app = web.Application(loop=loop)
    app.router.add_route('GET', "/plot", handler)
    app.router.add_static('/static', "static")
    ret = yield from loop.create_server(app.make_handler(), address, port)
    return ret


if __name__ == "__main__":
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Training graphs server')
    parser.add_argument('log_file',
                        help='path to train log file')
    parser.add_argument('--interval', '-i', default=30,
                        help='plot interval')
    parser.add_argument('--port', '-p', default=7777,
                        help='server port')
    args = parser.parse_args()

    loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
    loop.call_soon(plot_loop, args, loop)
    loop.run_until_complete(build_server(loop, '0.0.0.0', args.port))
    try:
        loop.run_forever()
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        print("Server shutting down!")
        loop.close()

This snippet can also be found here.

item.title: in guangzhou
item.description:
So I’m back after spending the last 3 years in the US.

Still a bit jet-lagged, I went for my visa interview today and finished within half an hour, while watching lines of people slowly moving, occasionally one or two arguing with the assistants. There’s so much heat, it makes the people short-tempered.

I took the subway home as I vaguely remember how to get there from this station. To make sure I studied the map, and found a few more new lines but the way home didn’t change. One stop before the transfer I decided to go out and walk back along the river. There it is, a new tram! A cute little tram that travels only within a short distance. Walking on, I discovered plenty of seniors and kids with nannies enjoying their day, and an open-air ballroom under the bridge where the dancing and the music happen. It’s definitely much more crowded and full of life compared to when I first moved in to this neighborhood, about 10 years ago.

More than anything else, I miss the food here. I tried rice noodles with Shantou beef balls in a neighborhood restaurant yesterday with my mother, it was awesome. I also made sure to eat curry fish balls from 7-11 that I couldn’t find in any 7-11 in the US. The old and trusted restaurants are still around, with plenty of new and upcoming competitors. But the prices seem to be 20% higher than before.

Banking and mobile services are disappointing, for anyone spoiled by the efficiency of the US. I spent more than 2 hours in the bank to do something that need not to be done ever in the US. I visited 3 stores just to find out the prepaid plans I saw online are not available in store, because of lower margin.

(To be continued…)

item.title: ghost easy upgrade
item.description:
Ghost is a really nice blogging solution. I haven’t updated my blog for such a long time and I am surprised to find out how easy the upgrade process is!

  1. download the latest Ghost zip bundle
  2. unzip
  3. cd into the unzipped directory
  4. rm -rf content
  5. copy config.js and content from previous version Ghost directory to here
  6. npm install –production
  7. npm start :)

Let’s hope buster still works…

item.title: lessons learned about jalapeño
item.description:
It is hot. Cut it using a fork, instead of fixing it with your fingers.

We were cooking vegetables with tofu yesterday. As usual Julio likes to add a Jalapeño into the mix. I cut it the way I cut other vegetables, using my fingers to fix it while cutting it with a knife. About 5 minutes later, I started to feel very hot in my nails. I went to the bathroom to wash my hands with soap, and accidentally touched my nostrils with my fingers. I felt it burning in my nose! And my nails! Soap doesn’t help!

The hot sensation lasted until this morning. I also accidentally touched my eyes with my fingers, HOT!

I am facinated by the power of the chemical substance in the Jalapeño pepper, and the fact that finger nails, nostrils, eyes can react the same way to that substance by generating the HOT sensation, just as the tongue!

I will remember Julio said that his mother cuts it with a fork, no touching with fingers!

item.title: after a long hiatus
item.description:
I want to write again.

But first I needed to migrate my blog from Octopress to Ghost. I was happy with Octopress until I discovered every update/push took forever because I have 200+ posts.

Migration was not easy. Took me almost 4 nights. Essentially the problems for me were:

I didn’t push the markdown files that are supposed to be under source/_posts to github. So I only have a bunch of published html files waiting to be converted back to markdown. During conversion it’s tricky to deal with Chinese characters, took me 1-2 nights to figure out. Loading Octopress markdown files to Ghost database. There’s a nice script available however some tweaks were needed to suit my use case. I decided not to integrate Disqus comments for now. Don’t worry I still have your previous comments in heart.

Please check out this repo if you’re wondering whether my experience might be helpful to you.

Finally I like the combination of Ghost + Buster + Github Pages as described here :) And I’m writing again!

item.title: Parallel Programming First Class
item.description:
Today I took a taste of Parallel Programming course from CS dept, expecting it to be about achieving parallelization using a low-level language like C/C++ with intensive knowledge on computer theory etc., however it turned out to be lectured by a researcher at IBM who introduced a language, X10, built on top of Java, with functional programming concept as in Scala. As X10 focuses on concurrency there’s new types and ‘struct’ as in C/C++. By using a simple example the class discussed common problems arise in concurrent computation, as appeared in using Hadoop.

Based on what I’ve learned today it seems the advantage of X10 is concurrency without the limitation of map-reduce paradigm. However X10 is still under development, and seemed to be only used at IBM. Its popularity should increase by time, especially for tasks that are found to be difficult to tackle with Hadoop.

Reference: http://x10-lang.org/

item.title: Don't Panic
item.description:
It is probably the best advice given to human race.

At first, it seemed the city was overreacting. Shutting down public transportation, stopping schools, gathering food and water. All this, seemed unreal until I lost electricity at around 8.30 pm Oct. 29th.

Few minutes before that, I had my tv turned on, following the news while I had dinner. A man in uniform knocked on my door and asked if I had opened my windows since there were some strange noise and other residents complained. Of course I didn’t open my windows and I heard the noise too! Fortunately I wasn’t the only one that found the noise unpleasant. I grabbed a notice on the door handle regarding the storm as he left.

Just as I was going to clean up, after a flash everything went dark. Oh, power outage hit me.

Don’t panic.

I didn’t have my flash light prepared, because I never thought I’d be using it. After a while scrambling over my drawers in the dark, I managed to find my small carry-around flash light but no batteries. But I knew I brought one with me from China. So all I had to do was look again, this time more carefully. Then I found one, and another one. But getting a flash light didn’t help. I could do nothing about the electricity. I went out to the hall way, all the emergency lights on, and nobody was there. It was quiet. I guessed nobody panicked, which was great. Then I came back, wondering what I could do. I dialed the numbers on the notice and confirmed the whole building was in power outage and there was no news about when it would come back. I looked outside the window, funny thing was I could see the border of power outage, just right across the street. On the left everything was dark, on the right everything lit up. And police cars were rushing towards the neighbourhood.

I couldn’t study, which was what I planned for the night. I had to save the laptop battery, it was charged about 100%. I got the Powerbank, also from China, to charge my phone. I sent msgs with friends and family, did the trash, washed the dishes, showered and flossed before going to bed with sirens and lights outside.

At 3 am I woke up, it was still noisy. It is always noisy here, sirens roaring from 11 pm till midnight all the way through morning. I tried the lamp, still dark anyway. Then I went back to sleep, hoping things would work in the morning.

Around 8.40 am, I got up and tried the lights, still the same. I still had hot water, everything except electricity. My stove wasn’t working. I had to think about my food. Luckily without planning for emergency, I had bread, milk, orange juice, tomatoes, cucumbers, bananas and green grapes, all of which could be consumed without cooking. But I’d like my milk to be warm. The solution was filling the stockpot with hot tap water and put my mug with milk in. So I had a nice breakfast as usual, warm milk and a banana.

I dialed the numbers on the notice again, no news for power recovery. I had to figure out what to do for a whole day and worry about getting to school tomorrow if subway service was still suspended. About 6.5 hrs of battery left on my laptop. So I wrote this post and then started reading the textbook to prepare for midterm on Thursday morning.

Around noon, I noticed water coming out of my tap much more slower than usual. Worried that I might run out of it, I saved some using pans and anything that seemed to be capable of storing water. About half an hour later, the nightmare happened. No electricity, no water. I couldn’t even flush the toilet. One can live without electricity but NOT without water! This was the moment that I really panicked. I needed a place to live! Survive! I had to abandon my apt! I tried to call management office to confirm the water outage, but they didn’t seem to know what was going on.

I was very lucky. After posting on facebook and a few text msgs, I had options of places to stay. I had been very lucky since I came to New York. Life is an adventure. You’ll never know where it takes you, especially in face of disaster and uncertainty. I’d never thought the following days would turn out to be one of the happiest week of my life, the happiest I could be in the shadow of the storm.

I left my apt in the afternoon of Oct 30th, came back in the morning of Nov 4th. I might have been the luckiest and happiest refugee. Everything looked intact. All I needed to do was some cleaning, and life went back to normal. I did have a secret small wish that I could stay longer as a refugee. But life goes on! And life is better now that I have all those warm and happy memories.

C’est la vie. C’est ma vie.

item.title: Working With SAS on Columbia Unix Server
item.description:
I’m taking two courses that use SAS this semester because SAS is rather widely used in industry. But it’s expensive and few students taking the same classes ever talked about buying the licence. So I have to use SAS on unix server, and this is rather painful experience.

  1. SSH into unix server is not a problem, but Kerberos authentication keeps asking for password whenever a connection is made, which means when SSH into the unix server and exchanging files between remote and local. having to type password over and over again is nightmare.
  2. SAS version on unix server is quite old, 9.1.3 compared to 9.2 in computer labs.
  3. the GUI of SAS unix can be launched by ssh -X, but it depends on the xserver of local, and I don’t like the experience.
  4. some command line options better be added when running SAS on remote, to suppress unnecessary logging.
  5. the SAS licence own by Columbia is expiring in about a month, SAS keeps popping warning messages in log file and there is no way to suppress them.

To address problem 1, solution I found so far is to obtain a Kerberos ticket valid for 10 hours so one does not have to enter password for a period of time, but it’s not a thorough solution due to the nature of Kerberos, there’s no way to avoid entering password forever.

The following is only tested on Mac OS X 10.8.2, solution should be similiar on Unix/Linux machines.

$ scp [uni]@cunix.cc.columbia.edu:/etc/krb5.conf ~/

$ sudo mv ~/krb5.conf /etc/
$ sudo vim /etc/krb5.conf
    # add the following in [libdefaults] section
    forward = true
    forwardable = true
    renewable = true
  :wq

$ vim ~/.ssh/config
    # add the following lines
    GSSAPIAuthentication yes
    GSSAPIDelegateCredentials yes
  :wq

$ kinit [uni] # enter password
$ klist # to check ticket status
$ ssh [uni]@cunix.cc.columbia.edu # should connect without prompting password

To make life easier, add some shortcuts

$ vim ~/.bashrc
    alias cussh='ssh [uni]@cunix.cc.columbia.edu'
    export unixhome=[uni]@cunix.cc.columbia.edu:[$home location]
  :wq

# login to remote server
$ cussh
# uploading
$ scp [local files] $unixhome/[remote location]
# downloading
$ scp $unixhome/[remote files] [local]

Each ticket is only valid for 10 hrs, which is a parameter set on Kerberos server. Ticket can be renewed before expiration by

$ kinit -R

Ref & further info:

  • Kerberos doc
  • Kerbenize ssh client
  • kinit automatically when necessary
  • Kerberos with PAM under Lion

For problem 2 and 3, stop by computer labs to use SAS 9.2 on Windows machine with GUI.

Some options to supply on command line:

sas -nodms -nonews [program.sas]

Other options to put in *.sas file:

options nodate nonumber nocenter ls=70 ps=80;

As for problem 5, hopefully Columbia will upgrade SAS to 9.2 or 9.3. Just see what happens.

item.title: 重複的夢
item.description:
某種記憶是一組相連的神經元，當大腦已經遺忘的時候，會突然出現，熟悉又完整。

前天的夢：牙齒脫落

睡眠中突然有意識，很驚恐，手一碰右邊門牙和門牙右邊那顆牙，它們就掉了，有點疼，又不是特別疼，繼續很驚恐，到處求助如何把牙安上去或者裝假牙，在驚恐中回憶起以前曾做過這樣的夢，但是同樣不知所措，在驚恐焦慮中又睡着了。

今天的夢：北韓間諜活動

睡眠中，意識出現，我，我父母，我的一個女同學，在一個北韓鄉村顯要人物家裏受邀吃飯，緊張的氣氛。我意識到自己曾經做過這個夢，而且結局是鄉村顯要人物家庭一位女性年長成員死了並且屍體送到我以前的住處，於是我努力想改變結局，要在夢中嘗試不同的做法。我想幫助那位年長的成員，她可能是僕人，可能是家中長輩，她喪命的原因是那位鄉村顯要發現我們是間諜而我們又幫助了那位年長女性。於是我決定，同樣地，要幫助那位女性，而且要在別人下手前保護她。在餐桌上，正如上一次夢境，緊張有序地進食，我作出的改變是提示同學和我一起到廚房幫助那位年長女性準備食材。在廚房我們與她交談，她略顯緊張，但也接受我們的幫助，僅僅是準備食材而已。飯局結束，我意識到那位年長女性即將性命不保，敦促家人趕緊回家，以防年長女性在我們家裏被殺害留下血跡作爲對我們的震懾。內心緊張外表鎮定從容地趕路，路上我靈機一動買了一大桶灰色塑料包裝的漿糊，和一桶白色油漆，必要時可以把門粘起來作爲抵抗。到家上樓時，見到一個大紙皮箱，可裝入一個人那種，還有兩位快遞人員等候我們簽收。我心裏很害怕，怕還是遲來了一步。誰知道，簽收時，包裹裏竟然是另一個男人的屍體，一個我們沒有印象的人。猶豫了一陣，我安慰自己，幸好不是她，正在想接下來怎麼辦時，電鑽響了我醒了。

經常在夢中，我意識到自己在做夢，並且用自己的意志去改變夢境，而不是由夢引導自己的思想。

item.title: 不務正業理想課程
